title: Tuesday, 12th December, 2017

alewis2005 morning all

Hold on, let's get the Gemalto rationale over with first.

11:12 am

42%/34% premium on 1 and 3 month volume weighted avg share price.

Flaneur M&A - Because shopping malls are the future....
PM11:12am

(sorry, i miss read you)

BE11:12am

17x earnings and 1.7x sales on consensus

fjp73 I'd advise some digging on it. very confusing set up for me, why have these sub cos, where the € leads back to all sorts of jurisdictions that the UBO is hard to identify.
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Credit Suisse's logic summary is as good as any.

BE11:13am

Deal rationale. On our estimates, Gemalto has sales split as 24% from Mobile SIM and services (~€750mn), 27% from Payment Cards (~€825mn), 16% from Govt Security (~€500mn), 15% from Enterprise Security (~€450mn), and finally 12% from Machine Connectivity (~€350mn). In contrast, Atos has revenue exposure of 5% to Security and 10% to Payments verticals. With this deal, Atos aims to build scale in 3 areas of overlap, with sales of i) €1.5bn in cyber-security and homeland projects, ii) €1bn in Payments business, and iii) €1bn in IoT/Machine Connectivity business.

BE11:14am

Core business at Gemalto has been under pressure, so good offer in our view. Given our view that GTO has seen material headwinds in two of its larger segments (SIM and Payments), this has led to sales being up only 1% in 2016 and down 6% in 2017 (const. FX and organic), with EBIT margins having fallen from a peak of 15.5% in 2014 to 10% in 2017 on our estimates. We expect this headwind to continue into 2018 leading to limited margin benefit from the €50mn cost savings plan initiated earlier this year. As such, we would view this offer from Atos as attractive for GTO shareholders.

fjp73 GTO don't have many options at all. They'll be lucky to squeeze a few cents more out.
11:15 am
BE11:15am

And UBS.

BE11:15am

Atos underlines three areas of rationale 1) Reinforced capabilities in digital cyber technologies and services and homeland security with total revenue amounting to c. €1.5bn (based on 2016); 2) Enhanced capabilities in IoT/M2M by leveraging Atos’ Codex data analytics and AI with c. €1bn in combined revenue; 3) Consolidation of the Group position as a leading end-to-end European payment services provider: The synergies between Worldline, Gemalto, and Atos businesses will benefit from end-to-end capabilities across the value chain and many substantial geographic, technology and services complementarities.

BE11:16am

The offer also implies 16x P/E for Gemalto ‘18E pre synergies compared to the 15x that Atos trades at now. In our upside scenario, we have a price of €63. This implies stabilisation in the SIM card business in 2018E (-5%) and growth reaccelerate in payments & Identity (+12%) with contactless adoption in the US. In such scenario, we estimate the company could deliver €3.32 of EPS in 2018E with €461m Profit from Operations (vs our base case of €403m) with the growth primarily coming from the action management is taking on costs.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

And that'll do, right? We should probably move onto the big M&A story of the day.

undefined
PM11:17am

So yeah, shopping malls.

11:17 am
PM11:17am

BE11:18am

Kinda a fun way to announce it too. Westfield suspended overnight, causing all sorts of wild speculation.

BE11:19am

Including interloping for Hammerson and going for General Growth in the States. We ended up triangulating advisors on various deals to try and rule out possibilities.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Turns out, it's the French.

BE11:20am

Unibail-Rodamco bidding $15.8bn

h1 Carpetright plc down..
Istrain Now who is a nation of shopkeepers?
BE11:21am

Starting with the domestic view, here's Liberum to say it's probably bad news for anyone hoping that a white knight might emerge for Hammerson.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Unibail’s agreed $24.7bn acquisition of Westfield makes the Hammerson/Intu combination look like a battle for the consolation prize and reduces the probability of a counter bid for either Hammerson or Intu from two potential sources (only Simon Property has kept its powder dry). Unibail has agreed to acquire Westfield in a cash and share offer, valuing Westfield shares at $7.55 (A$10.01) and a 17.8% premium. This creates an enviable platform of 104 assets across Europe and the US, of which 84% are flagship destinations. This has less geographical overlap relative to Hammerson/Intu, with arguably better quality assets. Synergies of €100m equate to 4.35% of the enlarged group's net rental income and add to our suspicion that the identified £25m synergies of Hammerson/Intu are low at 3.15% of combined net rental income. Prior to the offer Westfield traded on a CY17 P/FFO of 19.0x, which compared to Hammerson on 17.0x and Intu on 16.8x hence the valuation differential is modest. The Unibail-Westfield acquisition looks very compelling, particularly relative to Hammerson-Intu.

The theme here seems to be Unibail does A-list malls but lacks in the UK and US. Westfield does A-list malls but lacks everywhere except the UK and US. Both trade at a premium valuation to the sector and they fit together rather neatly, albeit with very little in the way of synergies.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Here's Kepler.

BE11:29am

While US physical retail structures are struggling to compete with online shopping, due to excessive retail density and department stores occupying too much space in the malls (28% of total sales at Westfield), we think that the jumbo malls will be one of the only growing brick and mortar segments in the future. At USD7.55 per share, the offer reflects a 17.8% premium to Westfield’s latest share price. No NAV has been disclosed for Westfield, but, based on the company’s annual guidance for 2017E, we estimate a c. 22x P/FFO (vs. c. 19x for Unibail-Rodamco). Our current TP is based on a DCF (WACC at 5.7%) and an adjusted NAV valuation.

Kiwi-juice Unibail buying peak valuation at rock bottom rates. Sounds like a great idea. Its EPS accretive as well
BE11:30am

And Morgan Stanley.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Both companies have a similar strategic vision but arguably with a materially different regional footprint. As such, the deal would plug the last remaining holes in Unibail-Rodamco's European dominant positioning (now also UK and Italy) and give the group access to a high quality portfolio in the US.

wayneJ @PM - think there is a bigger issue - A-list malls (general definition is a megamall ie > 1M sqft or 100k sqm) is more likely to attract premium brands and have restaurants / leisure and so more resilient vs B / C malls. This is why Hammerson + Intu makes only limited sense as Hammerson has spent a lot of time trying to be an A list player
Tom Dalgleish I always worry when a long time founder owner clocks off
BE11:30am

Concerns around structural headwinds remain, but asset quality should make Unibail-Rodamco materially better positioned than peers, all else equal. The business combination does not alter the structural headwinds impacting retail property landlords. But the asset quality of the combined group should create even more distance between this group and peers on asset quality, and on medium- to long-term rental growth potential

BE11:40am

Tesco clear outperformer: Food and Drink growth +4.1%. Outperforming Asda, the nearest competitor, by 200bps. Performance even better on a 4 wk basis with Tesco's food growth +4.4%, a good sign going into the Christmas period and implying 2%-3% volume growth.

Flaneur (@BE - so accidental robo-zap = perm ban?)
11:40 am
BE11:41am

Tesco total till roll growth (inc. gen. merch.) improves 20bps to +2.5% (12 wk) the best performer of the big-4. The gap to food growth is in line with management's explanation of stepping down in general merchandise which fell -2.9%, declining 50bps from the prior period. Tesco remains the best of the big-4 on two year total till roll basis, growing +4.2%. Market share losses were in line with the previous period at -0.2%.

BE11:41am

Slowdown in discounter growth is stabilising. The aggregate discounter growth has fallen from +19.2% in May to +14.8% in December. This is an 80bps increase from November driven by Aldi where growth has picked up by 200bps from 13.1% to 15.1%. Lidl's growth continued to fall to 60bps to +15.5%. In our view much of the rapid change in discounter growth reflects measurement error rather than their underlying performance. The gap to the big-4 growth increased 110bps to 12.9% (largely in line with discounter space growth and their higher food inflation).

BE11:42am

And Jefferies to round up the rest .....

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Sainsbury LFLs weakening as cash sales of 0.8% compare with the previous 2%, and against a largely unchanged comparable base. This appears mostly linked to softening non-food sales, which were largely flat.

wayneJ Question - as internet retailers mature will the market start expecting profits. And will we then find that in some cases physical stores are actually more profitable than online?
BE11:42am

Morrisons holding up against a very tough base as cash sales of 0.5% are exactly in line with October despite a 150bps tougher comp. Q4 LFL gains appear to be in the 0.5% region up until now, but we note another step-up in the reporting base in the weeks ahead.

BE11:42am

ASDA continues to stabilise, with cash sales growth of 0.9% confirming the business has coped well with its decision not to partake in the Black Friday excesses. Indeed, non-food performance for ASDA was the weakest among the Big 4, but partly offset by improved sales gains in food.

Key points of guidance are summarised below, although we believe the focus will be on “2018 illustrative EBITDA of c.$16.2bn at spot/forward prices” which compares to JPMe spot at $18.8bn. The company emphasises that applying the coal forward curve reduces EBITDA by ~$1bn relative to spot, while any by-products (including cobalt, and, for example, copper produced in the zinc division) are at forecast rather than spot levels. However, this is likely to be a focus for the call with management.

BE11:57am

We had forecast H1 European profit of £1.5m. Management had flagged a negative margin mix effect from service sales at the H1 pre-close sales update, but we were surprised to see the European H1 gross margin down 730bps (520bps from margin mix, 210bps from a deeper discounted programme, which has now been abandoned). The company expects some recovery in H2, with full-year margins down 4-600bps.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Management has guided to the lower end of market expectations (£13.8m-16.5m range), reflecting the huge levels of operational gearing that comes from 57% gross margins and 3% EBIT margins. On the positive front, current trading into peak remains robust and bed ranges have been fully repositioned ahead of the key Boxing Day sale period. However, the shortfall to our H1 European EBIT expectation is unlikely to be caught up; we downgrade full-year PBT by £2.3 to £13.1m, 14.4p EPS. We believe that management’s UK strategy is continuing to yield positive results. However, with two surprise downgrades from European margins and the bed repositioning, our confidence remains dented.

BE11:58am

PM11:59am

Here's their Q&A

Tom Dalgleish Is UBS an acronym?
PM12:00pm

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?

A: H1 PBT of £537m was c1% ahead of consensus £510-515m, with a strong Q2.

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?

A: Sunbelt accelerated to +19% rental revenue growth in Q2, including $40-45m (i.e. c4% benefit) of incremental hurricane-related work – underlying trends remain strong but steady on Q1 +15%. Yields +1% have improved vs. Q1 -3%, but again reflect some temporary hurricane-related benefit to rates that is now fading. Drop-through rates at c54% remain solid. In the UK, A-Plant was in-line with UBSe. Group return on investment remains stable at c18%, and Net Debt/EBITDA remains at 1.8x.

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?

A: Ashtead now sees FY18e performance ahead of its expectations at the start of the year, and has lifted capex guidance to £1.2-1.3bn from £0.9-1.2bn previously (UBSe £1.3bn). Looking ahead with 'confidence', Ashtead now aims for the upper end of its target 1.5-2.0x Net Debt/EBITDA range and so has announced a new buyback of £0.5-1.0bn (representing 5-10% of total shares outstanding). Post-US tax changes, Ashtead sees scope for an effective tax rate of 23-25% by FY20e vs. current 34-35%; all else unchanged, this could suggest EPS upside of above 15%.

Q: How would we expect investors to react?

A: With shares +28% since US hurricanes hit, a strong performance was already mostly priced in in our view, as is the US tax cut. However, the significant share buyback was unexpected and so we expect a positive share price reaction today.
